item.title: ASML
item.description:
Manager : Geoffrey Williams

ASML is world leader in developing and manufacturing photolithography systems and currently it is the largest supplier of photolithography systems primarily for the semiconductor industry and the sole supplier of extreme ultraviolet lithography (EUV) machines in the world making it possible to etch 5nm transistors for ultra high performing chips.

My current role at ASML is defining and developing the crash architecture for the next generation of high throughput DUV machine reticle stage to solve the chip shortage problem. In case of software and hardware errors the reticle stage moving components are susceptible to crashing into other components causing damage, downtime or even rendering the machines useless for future use. My current work aims at identifying components affected to achieve required performance specifications, its cascading effect on the crash architecture of the system and redesigning all the crash interfaces to avoid any damage in an event of crash so that the machine can be reinitialized with minimum downtime. A subset of work involves acquiring and understanding holistic working of the overall module, critical thinking to understand cascading effects of one design change, redesigning components, performing tolerance analysis and GD&T, aligning with required stakeholders, mentoring new hires, writing detailed engineering documentation, delivering presentations to wide audience of different domains and working with suppliers to get the parts made within required specifications.

In my pervious role at the company I worked with DUV NXT:2050 machines planning and performing interferometer experiments on reticle clamps for qualifying lifetime performance of the clamps under different reticle coatings. Work involved conducting experiments, diagnosing test setup, automating data processing, preparing documentation, co-ordinating with supplier to solve yield issues and analyzing data to make informed decision on next tests.

The following bullet points summarize the work done.

  • Lead engineer defining and designing the crash architecture of the next generation DUV photolithography machines
  • Conducted testing and analysis of complex mechanical and mechatronic systems
  • Developed Simulink models to understand system non-linear behavior and python scripts to automate data processing
  • Collaborated with vendors in defining requirements, obtaining feedback, establishing way of working and qualification
  • Designed a cleanroom machine tool to manually load reticles into chuck and thus mitigated the risk of vacuum pad failure costing $100,000 for rework
  • Performed interferometer measurements and data post processing to quantify nanoscopic wear on chuck vacuum pads
  • Conducted experimental tests to find coatings causing most wear on reticle vacuum clamp membranes
  • Co-ordinated and worked with suppliers to resolve manufacturing issues and production yield
  • Gained technical expertise in Siemens NX and part of tolerance analysis competence helping other with tolerance stackups and GD&T

item.title: Personal Projects
item.description:
FPV flying a custom made quadcopter

Custom built an autonomous and FPV flying drone using off the shelf components. The aim of the project was to successfully fly drone using GPS waypoint navigation autonomously and have some fun flying FPV as well. The project gave experience working with Ardupilot, electronic debugging of components, software understanding of flight control software, data analysis and processing using mavExplorer and mavProxy.

The main components used were cube orange for flight controller, dshot 1200 ESC's, 2300 KV racing motors along with video, audio transmitter and receiver.



Custom Built Laser Engraver



Custom made laser engraver engraving eagle on coaster

Images engraved on coasters using laser engraver

The purpose of the project was to get familiar with stepper motor and driver and eventually make a laser engraver. The individual parts were designed and 3D printed and then assembled together to achieve the required functionality. A laser assembly was also designed, manufactured and a transistor assembly was used to switch on/off the laser using the control signal from the arduino. The project helped understand working of stepper motor, drivers and generating machine code to achieve required in-plane motion. The engraved images on the coasters turned out to be better than expected.



Self stabilizing platform using Arduino and MPU6050



Built self stabilizing gyro platform as camera gimbal

The aim to build a self stabilizing platform was to understand I2C communication implementation between MPU6050 and Arduino. Enhanced understanding of the protocol implementation using wire library and also I2Cdevlib for faster implementation.



Selected 3D printed parts



Greek Meander Lamp

Julius Caesar pen stand

item.title: Matternet
item.description:
Managers : Brandon Landry, Sanjeev Sharma

Matternet is a Mountain View, CA based startup operating in USA and Switzerland in the field of autonomous drone logistics system. It provides an end-to-end solution integrating the Matternet M2 Drone, the Matternet Station and the Matternet Cloud Platform.

My role at Matternet is a combination of hardware design and programming. I am familiar with python programming language. A brief summary of my work is as follows.
  • Developed a test for measuring motor vibration and imbalance using accelerometer, loadcell and analyzing data using Fourier transform in python
  • Analyzed and compared NI load cell data acquisition systems and led the final procurement of the data acquisition system
  • Made windows apps using kivy in python for technicians to facilitate easy testing of hardware. The app issued mavlink commands via hard wired links and were used for batch motor and esc qualification, parachute deployment fuse test and complete vehicle test before deployment
  • Integrated the load cell and accelerometer data into the motor test windows app using python for a complete automated test with just one button click
  • Modified designs and assembly for the drone using Solidworks PDM
  • Performed structural simulation of drone fairings, calculations for minimum deployable height and systems level test for electrical components
  • Enhanced understanding of Ardupilot code and functioning, mavExplorer, mavProxy, mavlink, flight logs


Only a few work images can be shared due to confidentiality issues. The image in figure 1 shows an interface of the windows app made using kivy in python which is used for batch motor and esc testing and qualification before fitting in the actual vehicles. Required values are input in accordance to a predetermined profile shown in figure 2 leading to running of motors with the load cell and accelerometer data acquisition in the background all with a single button click.

Other apps for testing the parachute deployment system and full vehicle test before deployment were made for easy testing by concerened personnel.


Fig 1. Interface of windows app used for motor and esc qualification with customizable values

Fig 2. Ramp profile to be used for motor and esc qualification test

item.title: Composite leaf spring
item.description:
Student Incharge : Himal Agrawal
Project Supervisor : Prof. R. Byron Pipes

Abstract : Leaf springs are a part of the suspension system attached between the axle and the chassis of the vehicle to support weight and provide shock absorbing capacity of the vehicle. For more than half a century the leaf springs are being made of steel which increases the weight of the vehicle and is prone to rusting and failure. The current study explores the feasibility of composite leaf spring to reduce weight by designing, manufacturing and testing the composite leaf spring for the required load cases.

Brief Summary :
  • Developed testing fixtures in house using lathe, CNC milling and waterjet for prototype hybrid leaf spring
  • Developed composite layup tool using 5-axis CNC and manufactured glass fiber epoxy composite leaf using autoclave
  • Performed fatigue testing for different load cases and analysed experimental data from load cell and strain gauges
  • The composite leaf spring was lighter by 35% and withstood 1 million cycles without failure
  • Designed tests for small scale fatigue testing as a function of aspect ratio of flexure samples to expedite testing
  • Explored the fatigue properties of composite beams as a function of aspect ration to characterize shear and bending failure


Project Images:


Fig 1. CAD design of fixtures for testing in static and fatigue conditions

Fig 2. Manufactured fixtures for testing using CNC machining, waterjet, lathe

Fig 3. Laser scanning using FARO arm of metal leaf spring to determine geometry

Fig 4. Manufactured mold in 5-axis CNC using laser scanned geometry for composite layup

Fig 5. Trimming of cured composite leaf to required dimensions using wooden trim tool on 5-axis CNC

Fig 6. Layup of stepped flat leaf with silicon dams around to prevent resin flow

Fig 7. Manufactured and assembled hybrid composite leaf spring

Fig 8. Testing apparatus for static and fatigue load cases

Fig 9. Extreme deflection of composite leaf spring to check strength

Fig 10. Experimental location of strain gauges (red) to composite leaf spring

Fig 11. Small scale flexure testing as function of aspect ratio to speed up testing

Fig 12. Static flexure failure locations for unidirectional samples with aspect ratio 10

Fig 13. Stiffness as function of fatigue cycles for unidirectional samples with aspect ratio 10

Fig 14. Flexure fatigue locations for unidirectional samples with aspect ratio 10 indicating shear failure from stress concentration

Fig 15. Static flexure failure of samples for unidirectional samples with aspect ratio 30

Fig 16. Stiffness vs fatigue cycles for unidirectional samples with aspect ratio 30 - Almost constant, no catastrophic failure

item.title: Composite Control Arm
item.description:
Students Incharge : Himal Agrawal, David Kim
Project Supervisor : Mike Bogdanor

Abstract : The project aimed at designing, simulating and manufacturing front lower composite control arm using compression molding to take advantage of high strength-to-weight ratio of composite materials. A control arm is a hinged suspension link between the chassis and the suspension upright or hub that carries the wheel. The raw material was made by combining two existing advance technologies named Rapid Fabric Formation (RFF) from DuPont and Fibrflex from Fibrtec by the respective companies and offered high flexibility and drapibility for a thermoplastic resin formulation. Transversely isotropic properties for the raw material were determined using experimental tests to populate the material card and further used in Abaqus simulations. Structural simulations were then performed with composite layup using Abaqus for given load cases to satisfy the stiffness requirements. Changes in the geometry were made along with change in composite laminate orientations to study the effect of material orientation and geometric design.

Brief Summary :
  • Characterized the proprietary composite laminate material system for strength by performing tensile tests, shear tests, compressive tests and fracture toughness tests in different directions according to ASTM standards
  • Used MTS machine for loading specimens along with strain gauges and Digital Image Correlation (DIC) to measure strains
  • Analyzed the interpreted the machine data using Python programming language for different material properties
  • Used the material properties as input for composite laminate simulations using Abaqus
  • Studied the effect of change of geometry and material orientations on stresses and strains using Abaqus
  • Performed preliminary compression molding experiments using the proprietary material system


Project Images:


Fig 1. Prepared coupons for tensile testing

Fig 2. Tested specimens to determine strength along different directions

Fig 3. Prepared Mode I fracture toughness samples

Fig 4. Propagation of cracks while testing Mode I fracture toughness

Fig 5. Experimental force-displacement data indicating propagation of crack at load drop

Fig 6. Specimen failing in bending rather than crack propagation due to high bending strength

Fig 7. Fixture for performing IITRI compression test

Fig 8. Strain gauged samples for compression test for measuring compressive modulus

Fig 9. Shear failure in compression test specimens

Fig 10. Experimental setup for calculating Mode II fracture toughness

Fig 11. Crack propagation for different samples in Mode II fracture mechanism

Fig 12. Shear failure of specimens to calculate shear modulus

Fig 13. CAD geometry for stamped control arm to be made using compression molding

Fig 14. Process of formation of tow and fabric

Fig 15. Assignment of principal directions for composite laminate simulation

Fig 16. Displacement contours for bending and compression load cases of composite laminate

Fig 17. Modification of surfaces to reduce stress and displacement results

Fig 18. Geometric modification I

Fig 19. Geometric modification II

item.title: Compression molding of pin brackets
item.description:
Students Incharge : Himal Agrawal, Matt Boston, Rong Chiu, Deba Khawas, Siddharth Pantoji
Professor Incharge :Dr. Robert Byron Pipes

Abstract : The work presented was a joint effort of above mentioned students as the final project for Manufacturing of Composites 590 grad class at Purdue University. In the aerospace industry, ever higher strength-to-weight ratios are naturally sought. This has led to wider use of composite components throughout the aircraft. The most common, traditional methods for composite manufacturing tend to be slow and expensive, however. Part layup and curing times make even small parts take longer to manufacture than cast parts or weldments made of metal. Laminated composites also provide limits on part complexity, drastically reducing the design space allowed for engineers. Compression molding of composites provides a reasonable alternative that allows for relatively quick manufacturing times while also providing possibilities for complex geometries.
In the current project an engineered preform is designed in this experiment to accommodate a given part geometry. This experiment is the synthesis of many of the principles of composite manufacturing. An initial layup of the charge is determined using a stress and failure analysis. Experiments on the curing behavior of the resin system are employed in defining a cure cycle. The cycle is chosen to provide the ideal properties for resin and fiber flow, while trying to maintain an appropriate fiber volume fraction and minimize material lost due to flash. The parts are then manufactured and tested to evaluate their overall strength.

Brief Summary :
  • The project aimed at creating a part with highest strength to weight ratio for a particular loading and geometry by using engineering knowledge to make changes in process conditions and preform design. The geometry is of a part flying on the Boeing 787 Dreamliner
  • Stress analysis for isotropic conditions and ply orientation analysis was performed using Abaqus to minimize the Tsai-Wu failure criteria which led to selection of [0/45/-45/90]2s ply orientation for compression molding
  • Cure cycle was determined from experimental DSC experiments and preforms were cut on a CNC Gerber cutter with half inch cuts in the plies to improve fiber flow
  • One of the part was made with through thickness fiber reinforcements to study if the interlaminar failure can be avoided using fiber reinforcements in compression molding
  • Mechanical tensile test was performed to observe the maximum load carried by part and the failure locations
  • Microscopy was performed on failed parts to observe the fiber flow in compression molding and obtain insights into failure mechanisms


Project Images:


Fig 1. Image of Boeing 787 Dreamliner part geometry used for analysis and compression molding

Fig 2. Tsai-Wu value of a layer

Fig 3. The displacement along y-axis of each layup.

Fig 4. Plot of DSC data for resin system

Fig 5. CAD geometry for cutting prepreg : (Left) Optimal placement of +45o laminae on 11.75 inch wide prepreg roll. (Top Right) 90o laminae slits and peg holes. (Bottom Right) 0o laminae slits and peg holes.

Fig 6. Mold assembly: 3-part female half and 1-part male half.

Fig 7. Flash consisting of resin and fiber being squeezed into mold gaps.

Fig 8. Hole in laid up charge with z-directional peg for insertion.

Fig 9. Compression molded final part

Fig 10. Photos of final part with (a) pin and testing arm and (b)mounted on testing fixture.

Fig 11. Photos of Part 1 failure (a) while under load and (b) in a close view after removal from the fixture.

Fig 12. Photos of Part 2 failure.

Fig 13. Photos of Part 3 failure.

Fig 14. Load-displacement curves showing maximum load for each part.

Fig 15. Micrograph showing z reinforcement location before and after molding (highlighted in red).

Fig 16. Micrograph showing delaminations and cracks (highlighted in yellow).

Fig 17. The TEAM

item.title: Manufacturing of Composites
item.description:
Manufacturing of Composites : Understanding of composite manufacturing is essential to develop a complete understanding for designing a composite structure. The course taught by Prof. R. Byron Pipes at Purdue University aimed at examining the phenomenon involved like Darcy flow, permeability and compaction of fiber beds, thermoset reaction kinetics, polymer viscosity, property measurements, heat transfer, void formation, polymer physical properties, anisotropic composite properties, and residual behavior. The course developed theoretical and experimental skills in the following mentioned areas.

  • Polymer Transitions (Glass transition temp, degree of cure, visco-elastic behavior)
  • Cure Kinetics and Rheology
  • Darcyâ€™s Law
  • In and out of autoclave manufacturing (VARTM, Oven, Autoclave)
  • Thermal residual stresses and deformation
  • Percolation and transverse squeeze flow
  • Compression molding


Project Images:


Fig 1. Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC) for determining the cure cycle of the polymer

Fig 2. Experimental data from DSC to determine cure cycle for different temperatures

Fig 3. Thermocouples placed on bottom, mid and top of laminate to analyze the temperature distribution

Fig 4. Experimental data obtained from thermocouples for different location of thermocouples

Fig 5. Placement of polymer in DSC to determine degree of cure as a function of temperature

Fig 6. Experimental data for degree of cure as a function of temperature and time

Fig 7. Rheometer to calulate viscosity as a function of temperature, time and shear rate

Fig 8. Experimental data for viscosity as a function of time for different temperatures

Fig 9. Experimental setup for calculating directional permeability from Darcy flow equations

Fig 10. Experimental results for flow fronts to calculate directional in-plane permeabilities

Fig 11. NACA duct layup for curing in autoclave and oven

Fig 12. Final parts after curing in oven and autoclave. Extra resin flow for autoclave part indicates better compaction and less voids

Fig 13. Manufacturing of NACA duct using VARTM process

Fig 14. Final cured part from VARTM manufacturing process

Fig 15. Microscopy of autoclave cured part indicating better compaction and no voids

Fig 16. Microscopy of VARTM cured part indicating higher void concentration due to low compaction pressure

Fig 17. Possible responses of laminated composite ring after curing due to presence of thermal residual stresses

Fig 18. Composite ring layup on aluminum and steel tool to analyze cured residual stresses

Fig 19. Measured experimental displacements after cutting the composite ring due to thermal residual stresses

Fig 20. Compression molding tool for a pin bracket

Fig 21. Compression molded part from PPMC material

Fig 22. Microscopy image showing the flow of fibers in molding and knit line

Fig 23. 3D printed and machined tool for compression molding

Fig 24. Laser scanning of tool surface after compression molding to check for deformations

Fig 25. Deviation of the part from its initial geometry due to compression molding

item.title: Characterization of Composites
item.description:
Characterization of composites : With the advancement in technology to reduce manufacturing costs composites have found their way in the industries due to their high strength-to-weight ratio. Working with composites it is imperative to understand the direction dependence of properties of composites. The course of Characterization of Composites taught by Prof. R. Byron Pipes at Purdue University aimed at developing the mathematical understanding of directional behavior of composites along with lab experiments to validate the theoretical knowledge. The course developed theoretical and experimental skills in the following mentioned areas.

  • Micromechanics
  • Anisotropic Elasticity
  • Failure Theories
  • Microscopy
  • Directional tensile testing
  • In plane shear and off axis tensile strength
  • CTE of lamina and laminates
  • Open Hole Tension
  • Mode I and Mode II fracture toughness
  • Free edge effects
  • Compression failure


Project Images:


Fig 1. Effect of symmetric and unsymmetric layup on cured composite laminate

Fig 2. Microscopy of laminate to find fiber diameter, fiber volume fraction and fiber layup angles

Fig 3. MTS machine for tensile loading

Fig 4. Prepared and tested samples for orientation 90, Strain calculated using DIC and strain gauge

Fig 5. Analyzed stress-strain curve for transverse loading from load data by MTS and strain by DIC

Fig 6. Prepared samples for measuring shear modulus with strain gauges

Fig 7. Shear stress vs shear strain plot for data collected

Fig 8. Samples for off axis tensile testing to characterize strength as function of fiber orientation

Fig 9. Experimental strength and predicted strength as function of fiber orientation for different theories

Fig 10. Correlation of experimentally measured displacements from DIC with theoretical results

Fig 11. Flexure testing of samples as function of aspect ratio

Fig 12. Failure mode for longitudinal and transverse samples in flexure

Fig 13. Stress vs strain curve for samples with different aspect ratio in flexure

Fig 14. Experimental setup for measuring the coefficient of thermal expansion

Fig 15. Thermal strains along fiber directions measured from DIC

Fig 16. Thermal strains as a function of temperature

Fig 17. Prepared samples for open hole tension for different hole sizes

Fig 18. Failed specimens for open hole tension for different laminates

Fig 19. Corellation of experimental and theoretical results of failure strength for open hole tension test

Fig 20. Mode I fracture toughness experimental setup

Fig 21. Experimental data for propagation of crack with the increase in tensile force to calculate Mode I fracture toughness

Fig 22. Mode II fracture toughness experimental setup

Fig 23. Experimental data for propagation of crack with the increase in tensile force to calculate Mode II fracture toughness

Fig 24. Compression testing experimetnal setup

Fig 25. Microscopy of failed samples in compression

Fig 26. Failure mechanism for compression testing for different orientations of composite laminates

item.title: Injection molded pulley
item.description:
Students Incharge : Himal Agrawal, David Kim
Project Supervisors : Josh Dustin, Prof. Jan-Anders Mansson

Abstract : Feasibility of polymer composite material pulley viable for John Deere high power belt drive in tractors was studied. The increase in maintenance difficulties for cast iron pulley being heavy led to the decision to design lighter glass giber reinforced injection molded pulley offering the same stiffness, strength, fatigue properties and resistance to creep. Structural simulations were done from the given loading conditions and the geometry was redesigned to obtain the stresses and strains in the required range and favorable geometry which could be injection molded. Injection molding simulations were then done to find the fiber orientations, warpage, air gaps, weld lines from flow and the effect of these fiber orientations on the final strength of the part.

Brief Summary :
  • Performed literature review and patent search on existing available composite pulleys designs
  • Performed structural simulations for given load cases using Abaqus and redesigned the pulley assembly within the design space to account for stresses and strains
  • Explored the effects of ribbing, hybrid compression molding with carbon fabric and change in geometry on stresses and strains
  • Designed the gating channels, cooling channels, molds and process conditions for an initial injection molding simulation
  • Performed injection molding simulations using Moldex3D to determine flow induced glass fiber orientations and characterize warpage, residual stresses, air traps, weld lines and flow front progress
  • Performed structural simulation in Abaqus with flow induced glass fiber orientations as input to Abaqus model to analyze the effect of fiber orientations on stresses and strains
  • An increase in stresses by 14% was observed due to orientation induced directional strength from glass fibers
  • The final design was lighter by 71% from 105 lb to 30.23 lb


Project Images:


Fig 1. Original geometry of the cast iron pulley and belt assembly

Fig 2. Simplified geometry for large and small pulley for simulations

Fig 3. Stress distribution in cast iron pulley for given loading conditions showing probable failure locations

Fig 4. Modified geometry for stress distribution and stress concentrations due to 6 radial ribs

Fig 5. Modified geometry for stress distribution and stress concentrations due to 12 radial ribs

Fig 6. Modified design 1 for injection molding

Fig 7. Modified design 2 for injection molding

Fig 8. Modified design 3 for injection molding

Fig 9. Modified design 4 for injection molding

Fig 10. Stress distribution for final injection molded design iteration 4 showing probable failure locations for large pulley

Fig 11. Stress distribution for final design iteration 4 showing probable failure locations for small pulley

Fig 12. Injection molding simulation design and workflow

Video 1. Flow front progression in injection molding

Fig 13. Warpage in the large pulley as a result of injection molding

Fig 14. Location of air gaps and weld lines from injection molding simulations

Fig 15. Distribution of fiber orientations in X, Y and Z directions

Fig 16. Mapping of fiber orientations from injection molding using Digimat to Abaqus file for structural simulation

Fig 17. Mapped orientations to abaqus file for large and small pulley from injection molding simulations

Fig 18. Stresses from anisotropic structural simulation accounting for fiber orientation from injection molding which leads to overall 14% increase in overall stresses from isotropic simulations

Fig 19. Principal strains from structural simulation accounting for fiber orientations from injection molding

item.title: Formula Student Team, IIT Kharagpur
item.description:
Students Incharge : Himal Agrawal, Vraj Parikh, Siraj Modiwala
Project Supervisors : Prof A.R. Mohanty, Prof. C.S. Kumar, Prof. S.K. Panda

Abstract : TeamKart is the formula student team of IIT Kharagpur which designs, fabricates, manufactures and tests Formula prototype sports car. As a part of the transmission subsystem, I along with other members of the subsystem designed and implemented an electro-pneumatic gear shifting mechanism from the existing manual pull-push rod shifting mechanism for better efficiency and driver ergonomics.

The work involved studying the existing technologies available and modifying to the required needs. The design and selection of several components such as high pressure air source, solenoid valve, air regulators, two way actuators and electronic wiring with an Arduino was done. The components were bought assembled together to obtain a fully functional prototype of the shifting mechanism. Calculations were done to calculate the torque requirement for shifting along with actuator lengths and mounting locations. Finally the solenoid value was actuated by pressing the up-shift or down-shift button with the algorithm planned in an Arduino.

Project Images and Videos:


Fig 1. Designed and manufactured formula student car by the team

Video 1. Electro-pneumatic shifting

Video 2. Electro-pneumatic shifting
